name: rush
title: rush (HURRY)
definition: to hurry or move quickly somewhere, or to make someone or something hurry or move quickly somewhere

d_examples.content: We had to rush to catch the bus.
We rushed out into the street to see what all the noise was.
The UN has rushed medical supplies to the disaster area.

l_examples.content: I rushed to Tom's house, and when I reached it, he received me with a weird smile on his face.

name: rush
title: rush to do sth
definition: to do something quickly and enthusiastically

d_examples.content: His friends rushed to congratulate him after the ceremony.

l_examples.content: I was very happy and rushed to talk to them.

name: rush
title: rush (FORCE ACTION)
definition: to make someone do something more quickly than they want to do it

d_examples.content: I refuse to be rushed into making a decision.
Don't try to rush him - he needs time to think about it.

l_examples.content: It has always been very busy but these days people seem to have a harder time facing the fact that not everything can be rushed.

name: rush
title: rush (HURRY)
definition: when you have to hurry or move somewhere quickly

d_examples.content: Why is it always such a rush to get ready in the mornings?
Everyone seemed to be in a rush.
He was in a rush to get home.

l_examples.content: That's because we are always stressed and always in a rush.

name: rush
title: rush (ACTIVITY)
definition: a lot of things happening or a lot of people trying to do something

d_examples.content: There was amad rush to get tickets for the concert.

l_examples.content: She is that sort of a person who prefers to have more time on her hands so as to avoid the last-minute rush.

name: rush
title: rush (MOVEMENT)
definition: when something suddenly moves somewhere quickly

d_examples.content: She felt a sudden rush of blood to her face.

l_examples.content: To conclude, I believe that sports activities, apart from providing us with a sense of freedom and a rush of adrenaline, make us accomplished human beings.
